I'm a truck driver.  I know that we have to get the diesel trucks off the road and replace them with battery electric & hydrogen electric trucks, & use rail for more freight. Even though we are burning diesel for money, many of us still want to stop the climate change apocalypse!

For everyone who wants to know my thoughts, I am running for Congress, and I care a lot about the Green New Deal, but I also want to take care of the trucking industry, which supports over 9.5 million families Nationwide. Here's my plan in a thread: https://twitter.com/Joshua4Congress/status/1100989031360487426?s=19¬†‚Ä¶

I worked at Fort Hills during the construction which now boasts the biggest heavy hauler trucks in the world. 400 tonne I believe. They run on 4 electric drive motors powered by one small diesel generator. Use 1/8th the diesel I was told.
Yeah there are sort of hybrids for trucks.  They're most effective with light loads though.
for big docks and stuff, they were working on natural gas trucks for a while, they were freaking SWEET! But getting a natural gas tank onsite is a pain and so nobody could really use them :(

I think we‚Äôre all still on the ‚Äúwhat have now‚Äù track. We need to remember that technology doesn‚Äôt stand still. If we focus our thoughts and energy on the Green New Deal, we‚Äôll find a better way.

I'm pretty sure based off the majority of environmental scientists, even if we ceased to exist at this exact moment, the planet is doomed. They won't tell you that though, because there's no tax revenue in it for their government-funded research.
Only in 12 yrs, according to AOC!! The data has been manipulated and miscalculated by these so called environmentalist!
Sometimes we place too much of the burden of environmental change on individuals and not enough on companies who have a much more significant impact

There is that little factoid from the Carbon Majors Report that just 100 companies are responsible for 71% of the world's greenhouse gas emissions. AOC's critics like top-down economics so much. Here's a place where a top-down fix is needed.

You should keep in mind consumers keep these companies afloat. If people didnt pay for their products they wouldnt make them, and they wouldnt pollute. 
Yes companies cut corners but they do for consumer dollars. 
Change begins with people

None of us can match the US Military's or any given corporation's consumption. If all individuals stopped using oil the oil companies would continue to sell the vast majority of their product. Trying to pin the blame on individuals hurts people while failing to address the issue.

It also makes no sense to add fuel to a fire. Even if we only buy 1 more second of life in the planet by reducing our environmental impact, thats better than not, just so we can have a cozy easier life. And if 300 million americans all did the same thats nearly 9.5 years

It's very similar to that plastic straw ban. 60% of the Pacific Garbage Patch is fishing nets, 0.03% is plastic straws. So what do we ban first? It's all wrongheaded and misses the forest for the trees. Only the largest contributors can make meaningful change.
Is giving up plastic straws really that much of a hardship for you? Sure its only a small change, but a small change is better than none.

It also creates the illusion that we're doing something meaningful aboard the issue when we're not. I feel that's the much more substantial problem with these "fixes": patting each other on the back for rearranging deck chairs on the Titanic.

I do agree with that. People fall into a sense of complancey. In that sense I understand AOCs stance on incrementalism. But I still maintain that it is everyone's responsibility to fix the environment, and we shouldnt just point the finger.
